body:
I'd rather have it consume only 1 app name, and force the user to repeat the --ignore arg to ignore multiple apps.
It's more unixish
e.g.

``` bash
mackup --ignore appA --ignore appB
```

not

``` bash
mackup --ignore appA appB
```

body:

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,6 @@
+[application]
+name = newsbeuter
+
+[configuration_files]
+.newsbeuter/config
+.newsbeuter/urls
body:
`.newsbeuter/urls` holds all the links to subscribed feeds, should you have configured newsbeuter to store those locally, rather than using online services like The Old Reader, which is more secure since it means you don't have your login information in Plaintext, especially if you're synching your configurations.  
It's an optional, but I figure anyone that _does_ save their feeds locally, would want to synch those with their configuration to another machine as well, instead of having to set those up every time. 

With that in mind, and the fact that mackup seems to only copy files that already exist anyway (from a glance at the code at least) I opted to add it. 

EDIT: I checked and saving urls locally is actually the default set up, so I'd say adding `/urls` is definitely okay

body: Yes, IMO this change is unnecessary. I have verified that the current configuration works (had to set up a new laptop just yesterday) so I don't see any reason to change it. Perhaps the source of confusion - and why some folks think this is not working - is that the Sublime Package Control package needs to be installed manually. Once that is done, it reads some configuration files and pulls the other packages automatically. If we sync Packages and Installed Packages, probably that manual step would not be required, but given the author (of Package Control) advises against it I'm not sure if mackup should work that way.

@@ -0,0 +1,6 @@
+[application]
+name = Fisherman
+
+[configuration_files]
+.config/fisherman
body:
@sallar @laughedelic Hi :)

~/.config/fisherman is like `node_modules` in Node.js land, so it should not be "synced". 

The fishfile should be synced, however, as it works similarly to `package.json`'s `pkg.dependencies`, again from Node.js land:

Users running fisherman, can type `fisher` in their terminal and fisherman will proceed to install everything listed in that fishfile.

So, all you need is `.config/fish/fishfile` and also love, of course.

@@ -0,0 +1,98 @@
+# Guide for Merging Configurations Across Machines
+
+This guide is for users who want to combine configuration settings for two or
+more machines.
+
+For example, you might have some bash settings on Machine A (like useful
+command aliases) that are not on Machine B.  You also have some settings on
+Machine B that you would live to move over to Machine A.
+
+The problem is that if you use Mackup to send Machine A's bash configuration
+settings to Machine B, you will permanently lose any configurations on Machine
+B that you wanted to keep. Mackup obviously has no idea which features you want
+to keep and which ones you don't so you'll have to do a little bit of work to
+merge the different configuration files yourself before using Mackup.
+
+## Step 0: Read Through This Entire Guide First
+
+It will probably save you some pain in the long run.
+
+## Step 1: Determine Which Configuration Files to Merge
+
+First, pick the app you wish to keep in sync. Then determine which
+configuration files will be synced for that application by doing the following:
+
+1. [Install Mackup](INSTALL.md)
+1. Create a `.mackup.cfg` file in your home directory
+1. Add the following two lines to `.mackup.cfg`:
+
+```
+[applications_to_sync]
+<replace_this_line_the_name_of_the_app>
body: People might blindly add this to the file, can you specify in the previous bullet point that you are gonna use an application as an example, e.g. `bash` or whatever?
